entries.meaning: A strip of pleated fabric or paper used as decoration or trim.
(figurative) A substance or material on the edge of something, resembling such a strip of fabric.
examples: [...] the bright frills of the winter fungi on the blotched trunks of the trees;

entries.meaning: (photography) A wrinkled edge to a film.
(figurative) Something extraneous or not essential; something purely for show or effect; a luxury.
examples: Torontonians clutter their brick and stone houses with too much trim, or with window trim and shutters—and they also carve their shutters with hearts or maple leaves—but the snow conceals these frills;

entries.meaning: (zoology) The relatively extensive margin seen on the back of the heads of reptiles, with either a bony support or a cartilaginous one.

verbs.description: frill (third-person singular simple present frills, present participle frilling, simple past and past participle frilled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide or decorate with a frill or frills; to turn back in crimped plaits.
examples: Mrs. Sandham, formerly Kate Barford, is working at a baby’s frock, and asking now and then the advice of her sister, who is frilling a little cap.

verbs.description: frill (third-person singular simple present frills, present participle frilling, simple past and past participle frilled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete, falconry) To shake or shiver as with cold (with reference to a hawk).
(intransitive, obsolete, falconry) To cry (with reference to a bird of prey).
examples: The Hawk, as Falcon, Gawshawk, and all such Birds of Prey, cryeth, peepeth, or frilleth.
